   tomorrow, q1H neuro checks, continue propofol which is somewhat
   protective for seizures, repeat LP with opening pressure, MRI head w/
   and w/o contrast (ordered).
   .
   -Had increased pupil size 3h after 1st CT head. CT head repeated at
   1400. No change from prior. Per Radiology and ID - recommend MRI head.
   .
   -Pt was HIV negative as of 2 years ago - required to get green card
   from Kenyan embassy. Her 17mo baby is HIV negative (unsure if she was
   tested at pregnancy).
   .
   -Updated contact info: [**Name (NI) 8501**] [**Name (NI) 8522**] (cousin/brother, [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8508**]

   [**Doctor First Name **] - Charge Nurse/Boss at her work: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8526**]
   .
   -Plasmapheresis: catheter placed by IR, performed [**7-14**]
   -ET tube cuff didn't deflate when repositioning; anesthesia
   re-intubated
   .
   -Faxed order for HSV PCR on CSF on [**2184-7-14**] - will take 3-5 days to
   return as it is a sendout. Fax: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8527**] (attn: Lab); Lab main
   phone number [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8528**] (main lab) - call and cancel as we sent our
   own.
   -Medical records: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8529**]; they sent ER records from [**2184-7-13**]. They
   did not send her prior visits for malaria treatment - requested [**2184-7-14**]
   at 1630.

   bruising (may also partially explain her Hct drop)
   .

   MRSA pending
   .
   [**2184-7-15**] CXR pending
   .
   [**7-14**] CT head 1:
   There is no evidence of acute hemorrhage, edema, mass effect or
   infarction. The [**Doctor Last Name 1359**]-white matter differentiation is preserved. The
   ventricles are normal in size and appearance. There is a large right
   maxillary mucus-retention cyst; otherwise, the visualized paranasal
   sinuses
   and mastoid air cells are unremarkable. No osseous abnormality is
   identified.
   IMPRESSION: No evidence of cerebral edema or other finding to suggest
   cerebral malaria on this unenhanced CT examination.
   .
   [**7-14**] CT head 2:
   No acute intracranial abnormality. No specific evidence for
   cerebral edema on this examination. MRI may be more sensitive for acute
   changes if clinical concern remains
   Assessment and Plan
 ELECTROLYTE & FLUID DISORDER, OTHER
 AIRWAY, INABILITY TO PROTECT (RISK FOR ASPIRATION, ALTERED GAG,
   AIRWAY CLEARANCE, COUGH)
 MALARIA
   .
   Assessment and Plan:
   This 24F with recent falciparum malaria is evaluated for altered mental
   status.
   .
   * Altered mental status, suspected cerebral malaria - Patient had
   questionable seizure and remains altered. She does not have a known
   seizure disorder. Current confusional state may reflect post-ictal
   status or, less likely, nonconvulsive status. I am most concerned for
   an underlying CNS infection.
   .
   Bacterial meningitis seems less likely in the face of an unremarkable
   CSF wbc count, protein, and glucose. Her elevated CSF RBC count raises
   the question of herpes encephalitis - however would expect elevated
   protein with CNS herpes; suspect RBCs are [**12-22**] to traumatic OSH spinal
   tap.
   .
   She is not known to be HIV positive - though this needs to be
   clarified.
   .
   Among other noninfectious causes of her confusion, consider also toxic
   ingestion though less likely with her negative tox screens. Her basic
   metabolic panel here is notable only for mild hyperglycemia and an
   anion gap (see below). Head CT shows no evidence of bleed or mass
   lesion to account for her symptoms.
   .
   - Intubate for airway protection
   - Empiric IV quinidine. Consider discussing with CDC regarding
   artemesinin availability.
   - Will continue acyclovir for now pending HSV PCR though think less
   likely
   - Continue ceftriaxone 2g daily given increased risk of GNR infection
   in this setting
   - Continuous EKG monitoring while on quinidine
   - Follow fingerstick q4h
   - Follow parasite smears daily
   - Given concern for CNS malaria will discuss exchange transfusion with
   bloodbank
   - HIV
   - EEG
   - Add on Ca/Mag/Phos
   - Consider MRI head
   - Seizure precautions
   - ID recommendations appreciated
   - Consider neurology consult
   .
   * Fever
   Fevers are most likely due to malaria, as above. Other considerations
   includ aspiration pneumonitis/pneumonia given her altered mental
   status; however her CXR does not show any infiltrate. She has mild
   pyuria on her UA - ?whether her reported right flank pain may have been
   [**12-22**] pyelonephritis. No diarrhea or abdominal tenderness worrisome for
   an infectious GI process.
   - Malaria empiric treatment as above
   - Continuing ceftriaxone as above
   - Follow up pending blood cultures, add on urine culture
   - Call OSH for pending micro results
   - Obtain further records regarding treatment and workup from [**Hospital1 958**]
   .
   * Gap acidosis
   Malaria could cause acidosis. [**Month (only) 8**] be due to starvation ketosis given
   urine ketones. Not hyperglycemic to suggest DKA. Lactate is within
   normal limits. Ingestion a consideration but less likely with negative
   urine and serum tox screens.
   - Repeat electrolytes
   - Add on Osms
   - Check ABG
   .
   * Anemia
   Baseline Hct uncertain. With question of malaria hemolysis is obviously
   a concern - however patient's total bilirubin is within normal limits.
   No report of bleeding. INR only minimally elevated - think DIC is less
   likely.
   - Add on haptoglobin/LDH, fibrinogen, check peripheral smear
   - Follow CBC and coags [**Hospital1 **], maintain T+S, transfuse Hct>25
   .
   * Domestic abuse
   - Social work consult
   - Screen visitors
   .
   FEN NPO given altered MS
   Access PIV x2, ?pheresis catheter pending exchange transfusion plans
   PPX pneumoboots, PPI
   Dispo ICU
   Code presumed full
   Comm: [**Name (NI) 8501**] [**Name (NI) 8522**] (cousin/brother, [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8508**] (cell); [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8523**]
   (house)) [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 77**] [**Doctor First Name 866**] safe to call him, [**Doctor First Name 866**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8507**] (friend)
   -Do not let in [**Doctor Last Name **] Tah (ex-boyfriend)
   ICU [**Name (NI) 151**]
   Nutrition: NPO
   Glycemic Control:  monitoring

   DVT: pneumoboots
   Stress ulcer:  famotidine
   VAP:  bundle

   Communication:  Comments: [**Name (NI) 8501**] [**Name (NI) 8522**] (cousin/brother, [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8508**]

Summary:

The patient is a 24-year-old female with a history of falciparum malaria, who was recently admitted to the ICU due to altered mental status, fever, and respiratory failure. She had an unplanned extubation and required re-intubation. She has been treated with quinidine, acyclovir, and ceftriaxone, and is currently on mechanical ventilation. Her laboratory results show mild anemia, hyperglycemia, and an anion gap, but no evidence of bacterial meningitis or sepsis. Her head CT scan is unremarkable, and her EEG is pending.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cerebral malaria: The patient's altered mental status and fever are concerning for cerebral malaria. She has been treated with quinidine, but her condition remains unstable.
2. Airway compromise: The patient's recent unplanned extubation and need for re-intubation suggest that her airway is at risk.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is a concern, and she requires ongoing mechanical ventilation.
4. Sepsis: The patient's anion gap and hyperglycemia suggest that she may be at risk for sepsis.
5. Anemia: The patient's mild anemia may be due to malaria, but further evaluation is needed to determine the cause.
6. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's anion gap and hyperglycemia suggest that she may be at risk for electrolyte imbalance.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's hemoglobin and hematocrit are within normal limits, but her platelet count is low, which may increase her risk for gastrointestinal bleeding.
8. Infection: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and bandemia suggest that she may have an infection.
9. Meningitis: The patient's elevated cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) white blood cell count and protein suggest that she may have meningitis.
10. Seizure: The patient's altered mental status and EEG pending suggest that she may be at risk for seizure.

Recommendations:

1. Continue quinidine and acyclovir therapy.
2. Monitor the patient's airway and respiratory status closely.
3. Consider exchange transfusion to treat cerebral malaria.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte balance and glucose levels.
5. Consider consulting neurology and infectious disease specialists.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's platelet count and consider transfusion if necessary.
7. Consider ordering additional laboratory tests, such as a lumbar puncture and blood cultures, to evaluate for infection.
8. Consider consulting a gastroenterologist to evaluate the patient's gastrointestinal symptoms.

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the following information:

* The patient is a 24-year-old female with a history of falciparum malaria, presenting with altered mental status, fever, and increased pupil size.
* The patient was intubated yesterday for airway protection and is currently receiving mechanical ventilation.
* The patient's CT head showed no evidence of bleed or mass lesion to account for her symptoms, and MRI is pending.
* The patient received plasma exchange transfusion yesterday to decrease parasitemia, and last smear was negative.
* The patient is currently receiving IV quinidine, acyclovir, and ceftriaxone, and is being monitored for electrolyte and fluid disorders, airway protection, and seizure precautions.
* The patient's laboratory results show anemia, with a baseline Hct uncertain, and concern for hemolysis. The patient's INR is only minimally elevated, and DIC is less likely.
* The patient's urine analysis shows mild pyuria, and the patient has reported right flank pain, which may be related to pyelonephritis.
* The patient's social history includes a history of malaria treatment and workup from [**Hospital1 958**], which is being requested to be faxed.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

* Malaria-related complications, such as cerebral malaria, seizures, and hemolysis
* Airway protection issues due to intubation and mechanical ventilation
* Electrolyte and fluid disorders, including hypoglycemia and hypokalemia
* Seizure precautions and management
* Hemolytic anemia and hemolysis
* Pyelonephritis and UTI
* HIV-related complications, although the patient's HIV status is unknown
* Domestic abuse, which is a social concern

The patient's management plan includes:

* Continuing IV quinidine and ceftriaxone
* Monitoring for electrolyte and fluid disorders, airway protection, and seizure precautions
* Following up on pending CSF studies, blood and urine cultures, and HIV testing
* Obtaining further records regarding prior malaria treatment and workup from [**Hospital1 958**]
* Managing the patient's anemia and hemolytic anemia
* Providing social work consult and screening visitors for domestic abuse.

 MALARIA
   .
   Assessment and Plan:
   This 24F with recent falciparum malaria, presenting with altered mental
   status.
   .
   * Altered mental status
 Pt continues to be unresponsive, even when
   off propofol. Currently, suspected cerebral malaria as pt has h/o P.
   falciparum malaria.  Patient had questionable seizure and remains
   altered. She does not have a known seizure disorder. Current
   confusional state may reflect post-ictal status or, less likely,
   nonconvulsive status. I am most concerned for an underlying CNS
   infection.
   .
   Bacterial meningitis seems less likely in the face of an unremarkable
   CSF wbc count, protein, and glucose. Her elevated CSF RBC count raises
   the question of herpes encephalitis - however would expect elevated
   protein with CNS herpes; suspect RBCs are [**12-22**] to traumatic OSH spinal
   tap.
   .
   She is not known to be HIV positive - though this needs to be
   clarified.
   .
   Among other noninfectious causes of her confusion, consider also toxic
   ingestion though less likely with her negative tox screens. Her basic
   metabolic panel here is notable only for mild hyperglycemia and an
   anion gap (see below). Head CT shows no evidence of bleed or mass
   lesion to account for her symptoms.
   .
   - Intubate for airway protection
   - Empiric IV quinidine. Consider discussing with CDC regarding
   artemesinin availability.
   - Will continue acyclovir for now pending HSV PCR though think less
   likely
   - Continue ceftriaxone 2g daily given increased risk of GNR infection
   in this setting
   - Continuous EKG monitoring while on quinidine
   - Follow fingerstick q4h
   - Follow parasite smears daily
   - Given concern for CNS malaria will discuss exchange transfusion with
   bloodbank
   - HIV
   - EEG
   - Add on Ca/Mag/Phos
   - Consider MRI head
   - Seizure precautions
   - ID recommendations appreciated
   - Consider neurology consult
   .
   * Fever
   Fevers are most likely due to malaria, as above. Other considerations
   includ aspiration pneumonitis/pneumonia given her altered mental
   status; however her CXR does not show any infiltrate. She has mild
   pyuria on her UA - ?whether her reported right flank pain may have been
   [**12-22**] pyelonephritis. No diarrhea or abdominal tenderness worrisome for
   an infectious GI process.
   - Malaria empiric treatment as above
   - Continuing ceftriaxone as above
   - Follow up pending blood cultures, add on urine culture
   - Call OSH for pending micro results
   - Obtain further records regarding treatment and workup from [**Hospital1 958**]
   .
   * Gap acidosis
   Malaria could cause acidosis. [**Month (only) 8**] be due to starvation ketosis given
   urine ketones. Not hyperglycemic to suggest DKA. Lactate is within
   normal limits. Ingestion a consideration but less likely with negative
   urine and serum tox screens.
   - Repeat electrolytes
   - Add on Osms
   - Check ABG
   .
   * Anemia
   Baseline Hct uncertain. With question of malaria hemolysis is obviously
   a concern - however patient's total bilirubin is within normal limits.
   No report of bleeding. INR only minimally elevated - think DIC is less
   likely.
   - Add on haptoglobin/LDH, fibrinogen, check peripheral smear
   - Follow CBC and coags [**Hospital1 **], maintain T+S, transfuse Hct>25
   .
   * Domestic abuse
   - Social work consult
   - Screen visitors
   .
   FEN NPO given altered MS
   Access PIV x2, ?pheresis catheter pending exchange transfusion plans
   PPX pneumoboots, PPI
   Dispo ICU
   Code presumed full

   status.
   .
   * Altered mental status
 Pt continues to be unresponsive, even when
   off propofol. Currently, suspected cerebral malaria as pt has h/o P.
   falciparum malaria.  Patient had questionable seizure and remains
   altered. She does not have a known seizure disorder. Current
   confusional state may reflect post-ictal status or, less likely,
   nonconvulsive status. I am most concerned for an underlying CNS
   infection.
   .
   Bacterial meningitis seems less likely in the face of an unremarkable
   CSF wbc count, protein, and glucose. Her elevated CSF RBC count raises
   the question of herpes encephalitis - however would expect elevated
   protein with CNS herpes; suspect RBCs are [**12-22**] to traumatic OSH spinal
   tap.
   .
   She is not known to be HIV positive - though this needs to be
   clarified.
   .
   Among other noninfectious causes of her confusion, consider also toxic
   ingestion though less likely with her negative tox screens. Her basic
   metabolic panel here is notable only for mild hyperglycemia and an
   anion gap (see below). Head CT shows no evidence of bleed or mass
   lesion to account for her symptoms.
   .
   - Intubate for airway protection
   - Empiric IV quinidine. Consider discussing with CDC regarding
   artemesinin availability.
   - Will continue acyclovir for now pending HSV PCR though think less
   likely
   - Continue ceftriaxone 2g daily given increased risk of GNR infection
   in this setting
   - Continuous EKG monitoring while on quinidine
   - Follow fingerstick q4h
   - Follow parasite smears daily
   - Given concern for CNS malaria will discuss exchange transfusion with
   bloodbank
   - HIV
   - EEG
   - Add on Ca/Mag/Phos
   - Consider MRI head
   - Seizure precautions
   - ID recommendations appreciated
   - Consider neurology consult
   .
   * Fever
   Fevers are most likely due to malaria, as above. Other considerations
   includ aspiration pneumonitis/pneumonia given her altered mental
   status; however her CXR does not show any infiltrate. She has mild
   pyuria on her UA - ?whether her reported right flank pain may have been
   [**12-22**] pyelonephritis. No diarrhea or abdominal tenderness worrisome for
   an infectious GI process.
   - Malaria empiric treatment as above
   - Continuing ceftriaxone as above
   - Follow up pending blood cultures, add on urine culture
   - Call OSH for pending micro results
   - Obtain further records regarding treatment and workup from [**Hospital1 958**]
   .
   * Gap acidosis
   Malaria could cause acidosis. [**Month (only) 8**] be due to starvation ketosis given
   urine ketones. Not hyperglycemic to suggest DKA. Lactate is within
   normal limits. Ingestion a consideration but less likely with negative
   urine and serum tox screens.
   - Repeat electrolytes
   - Add on Osms
   - Check ABG
   .
   * Anemia
   Baseline Hct uncertain. With question of malaria hemolysis is obviously
   a concern - however patient's total bilirubin is within normal limits.
   No report of bleeding. INR only minimally elevated - think DIC is less
   likely.
   - Add on haptoglobin/LDH, fibrinogen, check peripheral smear
   - Follow CBC and coags [**Hospital1 **], maintain T+S, transfuse Hct>25
   .
   * Domestic abuse
   - Social work consult
   - Screen visitors
   .
   FEN NPO given altered MS
   Access PIV x2, ?pheresis catheter pending exchange transfusion plans
   PPX pneumoboots, PPI
   Dispo ICU
   Code presumed full

Summary:

The patient is a 24-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU with altered mental status, fever, and a history of falciparum malaria. She has been intubated for airway protection and is receiving empiric treatment for malaria with quinidine. She also has a PICC line and a pheresis catheter in place. Her laboratory results show an elevated CSF RBC count, which may be due to traumatic lumbar puncture or a CNS infection. Her CT head shows no evidence of acute intracranial abnormality.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cerebral Malaria: The patient's history of falciparum malaria and altered mental status make cerebral malaria a possibility. This could lead to seizures, coma, and even death if left untreated.
2. Bacterial Meningitis: Although the CSF wbc count is unremarkable, bacterial meningitis cannot be ruled out. This could lead to severe neurological complications and death if left untreated.
3. Herpes Encephalitis: The patient's elevated CSF RBC count raises the question of herpes encephalitis, although this is less likely given the negative HSV PCR result.
4. GNR Infection: The patient's increased risk of GNR infection in the setting of malaria could lead to sepsis and organ failure.
5. Acidosis: The patient's gap acidosis could be due to malaria, starvation ketosis, or other causes. This could lead to respiratory and cardiac complications if left untreated.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia could be due to malaria hemolysis, which could worsen if left untreated.
7. Domestic Abuse: The patient's altered mental status and fever could be related to domestic abuse, which is a possibility given her history of being a victim of abuse.

Recommendations:

1. Continue empiric treatment for malaria with quinidine and consider discussing artemesinin availability with the CDC.
2. Monitor the patient's neurological status closely and consider consulting neurology for further evaluation.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's laboratory results, including electrolytes, glucose, and coagulation studies.
4. Consider ordering additional imaging studies, such as an MRI head, to further evaluate the patient's neurological status.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's airway and respiratory status, and consider weaning her from the ventilator if her neurological status improves.
6. Consider consulting infectious disease for further evaluation and management of the patient's infections.
7. Consider consulting social work for further evaluation and management of the patient's domestic abuse concerns.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 24-year-old male with probable CNS Malaria, intubated for respiratory failure and altered mental status. The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 38.8C (101.9F)
* Heart rate: 90 bpm
* Blood pressure: 101/50 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 14 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 100%
* SpO2: 100%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 9.6 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 10.7 K/uL
* Platelet count: 497 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.6 mg/dL
* Glucose: 121 mg/dL
* Calcium: 7.4 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.8 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 2.2 mg/dL

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* General appearance: Well-nourished, no acute distress
* Eyes: PERRL (pupils equal and reactive to light)
* Cardiovascular: Normal PMI (point of maximal impulse), no murmurs
* Respiratory: Clear breath sounds, no wheezing or rhonchi
* Abdominal: Soft, non-tender, bowel sounds present
* Extremities: No edema, no cyanosis, no clubbing
* Skin: Warm, no rash or jaundice
* Neurologic: Non-purposeful movements, sedated, no paralysis

The patient's diagnosis includes respiratory failure, altered mental status, malaria, anemia, and hypovolemic shock. The plan includes:

* Continue mechanical ventilation
* Monitor ABG (arterial blood gas)
* Adjust tube position (12-23 cm)
* Monitor glucose and magnesium levels
* Follow-up CSF cultures
* Consider MRI of the head
* Maintain empiric IV quinidine and consider artemesinin
* Monitor ECG and glucose levels
* Initiate TF (total parenteral nutrition)
* Monitor I/O (input/output) and central access

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: Pneumonia, pulmonary embolism, or worsening respiratory acidosis
* Altered mental status: Seizures, status epilepticus, or worsening encephalopathy
* Malaria: Cerebral malaria, seizures, or worsening coma
* Anemia: Hypovolemic shock, cardiac arrest, or worsening respiratory failure
* Hypovolemic shock: Cardiac arrest, respiratory failure, or worsening anemia
* Infections: Pneumonia, sepsis, or worsening encephalitis
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: Hemorrhage, hypovolemic shock, or worsening anemia

The patient's ICU care plan should include close monitoring of vital signs, laboratory results, and physical examination findings, as well as prompt treatment of any complications that arise.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure and altered mental status. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated due to airway protection. The patient has a history of probable CNS Malaria, and his condition is complicated by anemia, fever, and hypovolemic shock. He is receiving treatment for malaria, including quinidine and artemesinin, and is being monitored for glucose and magnesium levels. The patient is also receiving nutritional support through total parenteral nutrition (TPN) and is being managed with stress ulcer prophylaxis and venous thromboembolism (VTE) prophylaxis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely to worsen without continued mechanical ventilation and adjustment of his tube placement.
2. Malaria complications: The patient's malaria may lead to complications such as cerebral malaria, seizures, and cardiac arrhythmias.
3. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen due to ongoing bleeding or blood loss, leading to further hypovolemic shock.
4. Infection: The patient is at risk for developing secondary infections, such as pneumonia or sepsis, due to his compromised immune system.
5. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's hypovolemic shock and anemia may lead to cardiovascular instability, including hypotension and cardiac arrhythmias.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status and seizures may worsen due to continued cerebral malaria or other neurological complications.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's hypovolemic shock and anemia may lead to gastrointestinal complications, such as nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.
8. Renal complications: The patient's hypovolemic shock and anemia may lead to renal failure or acute kidney injury.

Recommendations:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and adjust tube placement as necessary.
2. Monitor the patient's glucose and magnesium levels closely.
3. Continue treatment for malaria, including quinidine and artemesinin.
4. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust therapy as necessary.
5. Consider transferring the patient to a neurointensive care unit for further management of his altered mental status and seizures.
6. Monitor the patient's cardiovascular status and adjust therapy as necessary.
7. Consider initiating renal replacement therapy if the patient develops renal failure or acute kidney injury.
8. Monitor the patient's nutritional status and adjust therapy as necessary to prevent malnutrition.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health status as follows:

The patient is a 24-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU with altered mental status and a history of falciparum malaria. She is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. Her vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.1C, heart rate of 79 bpm, and blood pressure of 109/67 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 8.2 g/dL, and an elevated lactate level of 0.8 mmol/L. Her liver function tests (LFTs) are elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 13 IU/L and an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 13 IU/L. Her coagulation studies show an international normalized ratio (INR) of 1.2 and a partial thromboplastin time (PTT) of 24.9 seconds.

The patient's imaging studies include a head computed tomography (CT) scan, which shows no evidence of bleeding or mass lesions. Her magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is pending.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Antimalarial therapy with quinidine, which was started yesterday.
2. Antibiotic therapy with ceftriaxone, which was started yesterday.
3. Antiviral therapy with acyclovir, which was started yesterday.
4. Plasma exchange transfusion, which was performed yesterday to decrease parasitemia.
5. Monitoring for seizure activity and adjusting anticonvulsant therapy as needed.
6. Monitoring for signs of bleeding or coagulopathy and adjusting anticoagulant therapy as needed.
7. Monitoring for signs of infection and adjusting antibiotic therapy as needed.
8. Monitoring for signs of organ dysfunction and adjusting therapy as needed.

Potential medical complications that may arise in this patient include:

1. Seizure activity: The patient's altered mental status and history of seizure activity make it possible that she may experience further seizures, which could be life-threatening.
2. Bleeding: The patient's elevated INR and PTT levels suggest that she may be at risk for bleeding, which could be exacerbated by her anticoagulant therapy.
3. Infection: The patient's history of malaria and her current antibiotic therapy make it possible that she may develop an infection, which could be life-threatening.
4. Organ dysfunction: The patient's elevated lactate level and anemia suggest that she may be at risk for organ dysfunction, which could be exacerbated by her underlying medical condition and therapy.
5. Hypoglycemia: The patient's quinidine therapy may cause hypoglycemia, which could be life-threatening if not recognized and treated promptly.

Overall, the patient's condition is critical, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-year-old female who was recently diagnosed with falciparum malaria and is currently intubated in the ICU. She has a history of altered mental status, which has improved significantly since admission. The patient's recent EEG and MRI scans are pending, but her head CT scan showed no evidence of bleeding or mass lesions. She received plasma exchange transfusion on the day of admission to decrease parasitemia, and her last smear was negative.

The patient has been receiving IV quinidine, acyclovir, and ceftriaxone, and is being monitored for potential side effects. She has mild pyuria on her urine analysis and a questionable seizure, but no known seizure disorder. The patient's HIV status is unknown, and her blood and urine cultures are pending.

The patient has anemia, with a baseline Hct uncertain, and elevated total bilirubin. The INR is only minimally elevated, suggesting that disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is less likely.

The patient's current condition is stable, with a temperature of 37.1C, heart rate of 79 bpm, and blood pressure of 109/67 mmHg. She is receiving TPN and has a PICC line and pheresis catheter in place.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Cerebral malaria: The patient's altered mental status and questionable seizure suggest that cerebral malaria may be a possibility. Further monitoring and treatment are necessary to manage this condition.
2. Hemolysis: The patient's elevated total bilirubin and anemia suggest that hemolysis may be occurring. Further monitoring of her hemoglobin and bilirubin levels is necessary to determine the cause of this condition.
3. Infection: The patient's mild pyuria and questionable seizure suggest that an infection may be present. Further monitoring of her urine and blood cultures is necessary to determine the cause of this condition.
4. DIC: Although the patient's INR is only minimally elevated, DIC is a possibility that should be considered. Further monitoring of her coagulation studies is necessary to determine if DIC is occurring.
5. Seizure recurrence: The patient's questionable seizure suggests that seizure recurrence may be a possibility. Further monitoring and treatment are necessary to manage this condition.
6. Hypoglycemia: The patient's receipt of quinidine and her history of altered mental status suggest that hypoglycemia may be a possibility. Further monitoring of her blood glucose levels is necessary to determine if hypoglycemia is occurring.

   24 yof from [**Country 1773**] with probable CNS Malaria
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE -- intubated predominately for airway protection.

   poor quality scan.  Head CT unrevealing.  EEG (possible continuous),
   follow up CSF cultures (check for HSV), maintain mechanical

   ANEMIA -- attributed in part to malaria.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 24-year-old male from [**Country 1773**] with probable CNS Malaria, intubated for respiratory failure and altered mental status. The patient's neurological condition has improved, and he is now attending and following simple commands.

The patient's respiratory status remains critical, with mechanical ventilation in place. The plan is to move to an extubation trial.

The patient's altered mental status is attributed to cerebral malaria, with concerns including ingestion/overdose, seizure with postictal state or status epilepticus, CNS infection (encephalitis rather than meningitis), acute stroke syndrome, and malaria with CNS involvement. The initial CT scan suggests sulci effacement, although the quality is poor. Head CT and MRI scans were unrevealing.

The patient has a high mortality rate due to falciparum malaria, and is receiving quinidine therapy. He is also receiving empiric IV quinidine and consideration is being given to artemesinin therapy through the CDC.

The patient has anemia, which is attributed in part to malaria. He is hypovolemic and requires close monitoring of his fluid status. He is receiving TPN without lipids and has a PICC line and pheresis catheter in place.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status remains critical, and there is a risk of further deterioration.
2. Infection: The patient has a high risk of developing secondary infections, particularly given his immunocompromised state.
3. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status could worsen, leading to further neurological decline.
4. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's cardiac status is uncertain, and there is a risk of cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac arrest.
5. Hematological complications: The patient's anemia could worsen, leading to further complications.
6. Renal complications: The patient's fluid status is critical, and there is a risk of acute kidney injury or failure.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's nutritional support is being held pending extubation, and there is a risk of gastrointestinal complications.

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is ICU. The total time spent with the patient is 45 minutes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 24-year-old male who is critically ill with respiratory failure, altered mental status, and malaria. Here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Respiratory Failure:** The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated due to respiratory failure. The plan is to move to an extubation trial.

**Altered Mental Status:** The patient has improved significantly, but concerns remain regarding the cause of his altered mental status, including ingestion/overdose, seizure with postictal state or status epilepticus, CNS infection (encephalitis rather than meningitis), acute stroke syndrome, or malaria with CNS involvement (i.e., cerebral malaria). A head CT scan is unrevealing, and EEG and CSF cultures are pending.

**Malaria:** The patient has falciparum malaria, which has a high mortality rate even with appropriate therapy. Quinidine is being administered, and parasite peripheral blood smears are being monitored. The patient is at risk for complications such as anemia, fever, and fluid imbalance.

**Other Potential Complications:** The patient is at risk for seizure recurrence, electrolyte imbalance, and cardiac arrhythmias. He may also develop DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP due to his prolonged ICU stay.

**Lab Results:** The patient's lab results show anemia, elevated lactate levels, and abnormal liver function tests. His electrolyte levels are within normal limits, but his glucose levels are slightly elevated.

**Plan:** The plan is to continue mechanical ventilation, monitor the patient's mental status, and manage his malaria with quinidine and monitoring of parasite peripheral blood smears. The patient will also be monitored for seizure recurrence, electrolyte imbalance, and cardiac arrhythmias. Nutritional support will be held pending extubation trial. The patient will also receive prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

   Assessment and Plan
   24 yof from [**Country 1773**] with probable CNS Malaria
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE -- intubated predominately for airway protection.
   No evidence for active  pulmonary disease.  Good progress.  Plan to
   move to extubation trial.
   ALTERED MENTAL STATUS -- Much improved.  Attributed to cerebral
   malaria.  Initially found down, and unresponsive in the field.  Unclear
   duration.  Concerns include ingestion/OD, seizure with postictal state
   or status epilepticus, CNS infection (encephalitis rather than
   meningitis), acute stroke syndrome, malaria with CNS involvement (i.e.
   cerebral malaria).  No signs suicide attempt.  Doubt cardiac event.
   Initial CT scan (outside hosptial) suggests sulci effacement, although
   poor quality scan.  Head CT unrevealing.  EEG (possible continuous),
   follow up CSF cultures (check for HSV), maintain mechanical
   ventilation.  MRI of head unrevealing.
   MALARIA -- Falciparum.  High mortality rate on appropriate therapy.
   Quinidine Rx.  Follow parasite peripheral blood smears.  Monitor
   glucose, monitor Mg.  Transfusion Medicine consultation in progress.
   ID consultation in progress.  Empiric IV quinidine, consider
   artemesinin (available through CDC).  Monitor ECG, glucose.
   FEVER -- attributed to malaria.  Maintain concerns for other sources,
   related to malaria or other complicating infections.  Monitor cultures.
   ANEMIA -- attributed in part to malaria.
   FLUIDS -- hypovolemic.  Monitor I/O.  Now with PICC and central access
   (via phoresis catheter).

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient remains intubated and mechanically ventilated, which increases the risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), respiratory failure, and barotrauma.
2. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status, attributed to cerebral malaria, may lead to seizures, status epilepticus, or postictal state, which can further complicate the patient's condition.
3. Anemia: The patient's anemia, partly attributed to malaria, may worsen and lead to decreased oxygen delivery to tissues, further compromising the patient's respiratory status.
4. Fluid Imbalance: The patient's hypovolemic state, attributed to malaria, may lead to hypotension, decreased organ perfusion, and increased risk of organ failure.
5. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state, due to malaria, increases the risk of secondary infections, such as pneumonia, sepsis, or central nervous system infections.
6. Neurological Complications: The patient's cerebral malaria may lead to neurological complications, such as seizures, status epilepticus, or cerebral edema, which can further compromise the patient's condition.
7. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's nutritional support, including total parenteral nutrition (TPN), may lead to gastrointestinal complications, such as diarrhea, nausea, or vomiting.
8. Hematological Complications: The patient's anemia may worsen, leading to decreased red blood cell count, and increased risk of bleeding or transfusion-related complications.
9. Cardiac Complications: The patient's cardiac status, although initially stable, may deteriorate due to the underlying condition, leading to cardiac arrest, arrhythmias, or heart failure.
10. Renal Complications: The patient's fluid imbalance and hypovolemic state may lead to acute kidney injury or worsening of pre-existing kidney disease.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent or mitigate these potential complications.

Based on the provided physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 24-year-old female with a history of falciparum malaria, presenting with altered mental status. The patient has undergone plasma exchange transfusion on the day of admission to decrease parasitemia, and the last smear was negative. The patient had a seizure yesterday, and an EEG was performed with abnormal findings suggesting a very low voltage slow background at the beginning of the recording, likely due to medication effect.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: Temperature 36.7C (98.1F), heart rate 85 beats per minute (bpm), blood pressure 107/48 mmHg, respiratory rate 15 inspirations per minute (insp/min), and oxygen saturation 96% on room air.
* Physical examination: The patient is arousable to voice, follows commands, and has normal lung sounds bilaterally. The patient's abdomen is soft, non-tender, and has normal bowel sounds. The patient's extremities are warm, with palpable pulses and 5/5 strength.
* Laboratory results: The patient's white blood cell count is 16.3 x 10^9/L, hemoglobin is 9.0 g/dL, and platelet count is 359 x 10^9/L. The patient's serum creatinine is 0.6 mg/dL, and the patient's serum glucose is 167 mg/dL.
* Imaging studies: The patient's head MRI shows findings suggestive of venous hyperemia, which could be secondary to infectious or inflammatory processes.
* Parasite smear: The patient's parasite smear is pending.
* CSF studies: The patient's CSF studies show no growth on gram stain, no microorganisms seen, and no fungus isolated. The patient's viral culture is pending.

The patient's diagnosis is cerebral malaria, and the patient is receiving empiric treatment with quinidine. The patient's HIV status is unknown, and the patient is awaiting results of HIV testing.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Seizure recurrence
* Development of status epilepticus
* Hypoglycemia due to quinidine
* QT prolongation
* Hypotension
* Respiratory failure
* Sepsis
* Meningitis
* Encephalitis
* Stroke

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continuing IV quinidine for one more day
* Monitoring for seizure recurrence and hypoglycemia
* Following up on pending CSF studies, blood, and urine cultures
* Obtaining further records regarding prior malaria treatment and workup
* F/u with ID and neuro recs
* Considering continuous EEG monitoring and repeat MRI if the patient's condition does not improve
* Providing psych consult and social work consult due to the patient's history of depression and domestic abuse.

Based on the provided progress note, I will summarize the patient's current status and potential medical complications:

**Current Status:**

* The patient, a 24-year-old female, is currently in the ICU after being intubated for airway protection due to altered mental status.
* She has a history of falciparum malaria and has received plasma exchange transfusion to decrease parasitemia.
* She is currently following commands and has improved mental status.
* Her vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.5C (97.7F), heart rate of 85 bpm, blood pressure of 107/48 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 96%.
* Her laboratory results show anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 9.0 g/dL, and elevated liver enzymes (ALT and AST).
* She has a pending head MRI and EEG to evaluate for cerebral malaria.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Cerebral Malaria:** Given the patient's history of falciparum malaria, cerebral malaria is a possible diagnosis. This could lead to further neurological complications, such as seizures, coma, or even death.
2. **Seizure Recurrence:** The patient had a generalized seizure earlier, and there is a risk of recurrence. This could lead to further neurological damage and increased risk of mortality.
3. **Infection:** The patient has a history of pyuria, which may indicate a urinary tract infection. This could lead to sepsis, organ failure, and increased risk of mortality.
4. **Hemolysis:** The patient's elevated bilirubin level and decreased hemoglobin suggest hemolysis, which could lead to further anemia and potentially life-threatening complications.
5. **DIC:** The patient's elevated INR and decreased hemoglobin suggest a possibility of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). This could lead to further bleeding complications, organ failure, and increased risk of mortality.
6. **Infectious Processes:** The patient's pending CSF studies and blood cultures may reveal an underlying infectious process, such as meningitis or sepsis, which could lead to further complications and increased risk of mortality.

**Plan:**

* Continue IV quinidine at a lowered dose to treat malaria.
* Monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely.
* Follow up on pending CSF studies, blood cultures, and MRI results.
* Consider adding anticonvulsant medication to prevent seizure recurrence.
* Trend the patient's hemoglobin level and consider transfusion if necessary.
* Continue to monitor for signs of infection and sepsis.
* Consider consulting infectious disease and neurology specialists for further guidance.

Based on the patient's progress note, the patient is a 24-year-old female from [**Country 1773**] who presented with altered mental status and seizure activity, likely due to probable CNS malaria. She was successfully extubated yesterday and has been receiving various medications, including phosphenytoin, acyclovir, and doxycycline.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.7C (98.1F), heart rate of 82 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 111/58 mmHg. Her respiratory rate is 19 breaths per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 100% on room air.

The patient's neurological examination reveals that she is attentive, follows simple commands, and responds to verbal stimuli. However, she is confused as to date and city, which may be due to a language barrier or post-ictal state.

Laboratory results show that the patient's white blood cell count is 16.3 x 10^9/L, hemoglobin is 9.0 g/dL, and platelet count is 359 x 10^9/L. Her liver enzymes, including ALT and AST, are elevated. The patient's electrolyte levels, including sodium, potassium, and magnesium, are within normal limits.

Imaging studies, including an MRI head and EEG, have been reviewed, but no focal abnormalities were detected. A parasite smear is pending, and CSF HSV and cx cultures are also pending.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

1. Altered mental status: The patient's mental status is presumed to be due to cerebral malaria, and she is being monitored closely for any changes. Repeat EEG may be necessary if her status changes.
2. Malaria: The patient has falciparum malaria, and she will continue to receive IV quinidine and PO doxycycline to complete her treatment course.
3. Seizure: The patient's seizure activity is likely due to CSF infection or malaria, and she has been loaded with phosphenytoin. Further neurology recommendations are needed regarding further imaging or repeat EEG.
4. UTI: The patient has a history of uncomplicated UTI, and she has been treated with antibiotics.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia is attributed to malaria, and her hemoglobin level is stable.
6. Domestic violence hx/social situation/depression: The patient has a history of depression and prior suicidal gestures, and she is being evaluated by social work and psychology for further support.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

1. Cerebral edema: The patient's altered mental status and seizure activity may be due to cerebral edema, which can lead to increased intracranial pressure and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory rate is slightly elevated, and she may be at risk for respiratory failure if her condition deteriorates.
3. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and liver enzymes may indicate a septic response, which can lead to multi-organ dysfunction and potentially life-threatening complications.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's anemia and potential sepsis may increase her risk for gastrointestinal bleeding, which can lead to hemorrhagic shock and potentially life-threatening complications.
5. Psychiatric complications: The patient's history of depression and prior suicidal gestures may increase her risk for psychiatric complications, including suicidal ideation or behavior, which can lead to potentially life-threatening consequences.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 24-year-old female from Country 1773 who was admitted with altered mental status and probable CNS Malaria. The patient's condition has improved, but there are still potential medical complications that can arise.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.7C (98.1F), heart rate of 82 bpm, and blood pressure of 111/58 mmHg. The patient is receiving IV quinidine for malaria treatment and has been loaded with fosphenytoin for seizure prophylaxis.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 9.0 g/dL. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, with the exception of a slightly elevated potassium level of 4.4 mmol/L.

The patient's imaging studies, including an MRI head and EEG, are normal. The patient's parasite smear is pending, and the CSF HSV and CX growth are also pending.

The patient's assessment and plan include continued monitoring of her mental status, seizure activity, and glucose levels. The patient is also being treated for malaria with IV quinidine and will be transitioned to doxycycline when able to take oral medications.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Seizure activity: The patient has had a brief seizure episode in the past, and it is essential to continue monitoring her for seizure activity and consider repeat EEG if necessary.
2. Malaria treatment failure: The patient's malaria treatment may not be effective, and it is crucial to monitor her parasite peripheral blood smears and adjust treatment accordingly.
3. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen, and it is essential to monitor her hemoglobin levels and consider transfusions if necessary.
4. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient's electrolyte levels, particularly potassium, should be closely monitored to prevent imbalances.
5. Infection: The patient is at risk for infection, particularly urinary tract infection, and it is essential to monitor her urine output and consider antibiotic treatment if necessary.
6. Depression and suicidal ideation: The patient has a history of depression and suicidal ideation, and it is crucial to continue monitoring her mental status and provide appropriate counseling and support.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential medical complications and ensure optimal treatment and recovery.

Summary:

The patient is a 53.4 kg individual admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of altered mental status and seizures. They were previously treated with antibiotics, including ceftriaxone and acyclovir, and were started on quinidine drip. Due to the patient pulling out their PICC line, a PIV was placed, and TPN and quinidine drip were continued. The patient was started on dilantin 100mg TID, with daily dilantin trough levels to be monitored. Neuroimaging was not performed due to psychomotor slowing without focal deficits. The patient was diagnosed with hypoactive delirium and was referred to a psychiatrist for further evaluation.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.2C (98.9F), heart rate of 69-88 bpm, and blood pressure of 101/73 mmHg. Their respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 99%. The patient's physical examination is unremarkable, with clear lung fields, regular heart rhythm, and no signs of organomegaly or masses.

Lab results show:

* White blood cell count: 12.9-14.3 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 9.4-9.1 g/dL
* Platelet count: 346-359 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.4-0.6 mg/dL
* Glucose: 119-126 mg/dL
* Electrolytes: Na 140 mEq/L, K 4.1 mEq/L, Cl 106 mEq/L
* Liver function tests: ALT 24 IU/L, AST 26 IU/L, Alk Phos 64 IU/L, T Bili 0.6 mg/dL
* Coagulation studies: PT 13.8 seconds, PTT 24.9 seconds, INR 1.2

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Electrolyte and fluid disorder: The patient's electrolyte levels are slightly abnormal, and their fluid balance is negative. This can lead to electrolyte imbalances, cardiac arrhythmias, and other complications.
2. Malaria: Although the parasite smear was negative, the patient is at risk for malaria due to their travel history.
3. Seizures: The patient's seizure activity may not be fully controlled, and they may be at risk for further seizures.
4. Delirium: The patient's hypoactive delirium may not be fully resolved, and they may be at risk for further cognitive decline.
5. Infection: The patient's underlying infection may not be fully treated, and they may be at risk for further infection.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's platelet count is slightly low, and they may be at risk for gastrointestinal bleeding.
7. Renal dysfunction: The patient's creatinine levels are slightly elevated, and they may be at risk for renal dysfunction.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and lab results closely.
2. Adjust the patient's medication regimen as necessary to control their seizure activity and manage their electrolyte imbalances.
3. Consider further evaluation and treatment for the patient's hypoactive delirium.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's fluid balance and electrolyte levels.
5. Consider further evaluation and treatment for the patient's underlying infection.
6. Monitor the patient's platelet count and consider platelet transfusions if necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's renal function and consider further evaluation and treatment if necessary.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-hour-old ICU admission with a chief complaint of altered mental status. The patient has been experiencing hypoactive delirium, which is being managed with medication. The patient has a history of seizure activity, and dilantin has been started to help manage this. The patient has a PICC line that was pulled out and replaced with a PIV, and is receiving TPN and quinidine drip. The patient has a pending parasite smear, phenytoin level, and CSF studies, and has had negative results for HSV PCR and CSF cx.

Potential medical complications:

1. Electrolyte and fluid disorder: The patient's electrolyte levels are abnormal, with a potassium level of 3.6 mmol/L and a phosphorus level of 1.4 mg/dL. This could lead to muscle weakness, fatigue, and cardiac arrhythmias.
2. Airway, inability to protect: The patient has an altered mental status and is at risk for aspiration, altered gag reflex, and impaired airway clearance, which could lead to respiratory failure.
3. Malaria: The patient has a pending parasite smear, which could indicate the presence of malaria. If left untreated, malaria could lead to serious complications, including organ failure and death.
4. Seizure activity: The patient has a history of seizure activity and is receiving dilantin to help manage this. If the dilantin level is not monitored and adjusted, the patient could experience seizure activity, which could lead to respiratory failure and cardiac arrest.
5. Hypoglycemia: The patient's glucose level is 126 mg/dL, which is slightly elevated. However, if the patient's glucose level drops too low, it could lead to seizures, coma, and even death.
6. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte levels are abnormal, which could lead to muscle weakness, fatigue, and cardiac arrhythmias.
7. Fluid overload: The patient has received a significant amount of fluid, which could lead to fluid overload and pulmonary edema.
8. Infection: The patient has a pending CSF cx, which could indicate the presence of an infection. If left untreated, this could lead to serious complications, including meningitis and sepsis.

Overall, the patient is at risk for several medical complications, including electrolyte and fluid disorders, airway compromise, malaria, seizure activity, hypoglycemia, electrolyte imbalance, fluid overload, and infection. It is essential to monitor the patient's condition closely and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent these complications.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 24-year-old female with a recent history of falciparum malaria, presenting with altered mental status. The patient's mental status has improved significantly since admission, and she is now following commands. However, other causes of her confusional state must be considered, including cerebral malaria, toxic ingestion, and nonconvulsive status.

The patient has had a seizure, and an EEG was performed, which showed no focal deficits. A continuous 24-hour EEG is being monitored, and a repeat MRI may be necessary if the patient's mental status does not improve.

The patient is being treated with IV quinidine for one more day, and if she has any side effects, she will be contacted by the ID team. The patient's HSV PCR results are pending, and if they are negative, acyclovir can be discontinued.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia, with a baseline Hct uncertain. Hemolysis labs are unremarkable, and coagulation studies are normal, making DIC less likely. The patient's CBC will be followed.

The patient has a history of depression and suicide attempts, and she is also a victim of domestic abuse. A psych consult and social work consult have been ordered to address these issues.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Cerebral malaria: The patient's altered mental status and seizure could be indicative of cerebral malaria, which can lead to severe neurological complications, including coma and death.
2. Toxic ingestion: The patient's altered mental status could be due to toxic ingestion, which can lead to severe neurological and systemic complications.
3. Nonconvulsive status: The patient's altered mental status could be due to nonconvulsive status, which can lead to prolonged hospitalization and potential long-term neurological sequelae.
4. Infection: The patient's altered mental status could be due to an underlying infection, such as bacterial meningitis or tuberculosis, which can lead to severe neurological and systemic complications.
5. Hypoglycemia: The patient's altered mental status could be due to hypoglycemia, which can lead to severe neurological and systemic complications.

In terms of medication, the patient is currently receiving IV quinidine, and her anticonvulsant medication has been changed to dilantin. She is also receiving antibiotics for a potential UTI.

In terms of lab results, the patient's WBC count is 12.9, Hct is 23.5, and platelet count is 346. Her blood glucose levels are within normal range. Her liver function tests (LFTs) are slightly elevated, and her renal function tests (RFTs) are normal.

In terms of imaging studies, the patient's MRI showed findings consistent with infection/inflammation. Her EEG showed no focal deficits.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 24-year-old female with a history of falciparum malaria, presenting with altered mental status. She received plasma exchange transfusion on the day of admission to decrease parasitemia. The patient's mental status has improved significantly since admission, and she is now following commands.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.2C (98.9F), heart rate of 69 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 101/73 mmHg. Her respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 99% on room air.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 12.9, hemoglobin of 9.4 g/dL, and platelet count of 346,000. Her liver function tests are mildly elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase of 24 U/L and an alanine aminotransferase of 26 U/L. Her renal function is normal, with a creatinine of 0.6 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen of 27 mg/dL.

The patient's medical history is significant for depression, suicide attempts, and domestic abuse. She is currently receiving treatment for malaria, including quinidine, and is being monitored for potential seizures.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Seizure recurrence: The patient has had a seizure in the past, and it is possible that she may experience another seizure while in the ICU.
2. Malaria relapse: Despite treatment, the patient's malaria may relapse, which could lead to further complications.
3. Infection: The patient is at risk for developing infections, particularly given her compromised immune system.
4. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient may require additional nutritional support to ensure she is receiving adequate calories and nutrients.
5. Depression and anxiety: The patient's history of depression and anxiety may continue to pose a risk for her mental health while in the ICU.
6. Domestic violence: The patient's history of domestic abuse may continue to pose a risk for her safety while in the ICU.

The patient's plan of care includes continuing treatment for malaria, monitoring for potential seizures, and providing nutritional support. The patient's mental health will also be closely monitored, and she will be referred to a psychiatrist for further evaluation and treatment.

Summary:

The patient is a [age] year-old female admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of altered mental status. She was previously diagnosed with hypoactive delirium and is being treated with quinidine drip. The patient's condition has been stable, with no significant changes in her vital signs or laboratory results. She has been experiencing psychomotor slowing, but no focal deficits have been noted. The patient has been placed on a PIV catheter with a pheresis catheter, and TPN has been continued. Dilantin has been started to manage seizures, and daily dilantin levels will be monitored. The patient's electrolyte and fluid disorder is being managed, and she is at risk for aspiration due to her inability to protect her airway.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Seizure activity: The patient is at risk for seizure activity due to her hypoactive delirium and the use of quinidine drip. Close monitoring of her seizure activity and management of her dilantin levels are crucial to prevent further complications.
2. Aspiration: The patient's inability to protect her airway increases her risk of aspiration. Close monitoring of her airway and management of her electrolyte and fluid disorder are essential to prevent aspiration.
3. Malaria: The patient's CSF studies are pending, and she has been treated with acyclovir. Close monitoring of her CSF results and management of her malaria symptoms are crucial to prevent further complications.
4. Electrolyte and fluid disorder: The patient's electrolyte and fluid disorder is being managed, but close monitoring of her electrolyte and fluid levels is essential to prevent further complications.
5. Infection: The patient is at risk for infection due to her prolonged stay in the ICU. Close monitoring of her vital signs and laboratory results is essential to detect any signs of infection early.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to closely monitor the patient's seizure activity and manage her dilantin levels to prevent further complications.
2. Continue to manage the patient's electrolyte and fluid disorder to prevent aspiration and other complications.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's CSF results and manage her malaria symptoms to prevent further complications.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results to detect any signs of infection early.
5. Consider consulting with a neurologist to further manage the patient's hypoactive delirium and seizure activity.

   This 24F with recent falciparum malaria, presenting with altered mental

   of admission to decrease parasitemia. Last smear negative. However,
   other causes must be considered. Patient had seizure yesterday,
   although no known seizure disorder. Current confusional state may
   reflect post-ictal status or, less likely, nonconvulsive status. EEG
   performed yesterday with results above. LP does not suggest bacterial
   meningitis or TB meningitis. HIV status unknown although pt negative 2
   y ago per friends. Toxic ingestion less likely as tox screens negative
   (Benzo
s positive most likely b/c pt received ativan for ?seizure).

s chart. QTc
   this AM was normal.
   - F/u HSV PCR at [**Hospital1 958**]
 if negative, can d/c acyclovir. Also, would
   expect MRI changes if this is HSV.
   - Completed 3 days of ceftriaxone for uncomplicated UTI
   - F/u blood, urine, CSF studies (sent for cultures, HSV PCR, Lyme, EEE,
   West [**Doctor First Name 3223**] per ID recs)
   - EKG [**Hospital1 **] to evaluate for QT prolongation
   - Follow fingerstick q4h as quinidine can cause hypoglycemia
   - Follow parasite smears [**Hospital1 **]
 will check with ID as to when they can
   be d/c
d as they have been negative to date.
   - HIV status once pt able to give consent.
   - Seizure precautions
   -Neuro- if pt is not herself, will do continuous EEG monitoring and
   repeat MRI
   -t/b with family/friends as to whether pt is at her baseline
   .
   * Fever
 Resolved. Most likely due to malaria.
   - Malaria empiric treatment as above
   - Follow up pending CSF Studies, blood and urine cultures
   - Call OSH for pending micro results
   - Obtain further records regarding prior malaria treatment and workup
   from [**Hospital1 958**]
 request faxed [**2184-7-14**] at 1400. Medical Records number in

   .
   * Anemia - Baseline Hct uncertain. Hemolysis labs unremarkable. Coags
   nl so DIC less likely.

   .

Summary:

The patient is a 24-year-old female admitted to the ICU with altered mental status, suspected cerebral malaria, and a history of falciparum malaria. She has undergone plasma exchange transfusion and is currently receiving quinidine drip. Her mental status has improved, but she is still confused and has a language barrier. She had a seizure yesterday, and her EEG showed no focal deficits. She is also experiencing back pain, which is being evaluated with an L-spine order. Her labs show anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated liver enzymes. She is also being treated for a UTI and has a pending HIV status.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cerebral malaria: The patient's altered mental status and seizure activity suggest cerebral malaria, which is a life-threatening condition that requires prompt treatment.
2. Seizure activity: The patient's history of seizure disorder and recent seizure activity pose a risk for further seizures, which can be life-threatening.
3. Anemia: The patient's anemia may be related to hemolysis or bone marrow suppression, which can be caused by various medications or underlying medical conditions.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's low platelet count may be related to bone marrow suppression or disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), which can increase the risk of bleeding.
5. Liver dysfunction: The patient's elevated liver enzymes may indicate liver damage or dysfunction, which can be caused by various medications or underlying medical conditions.
6. UTI: The patient's UTI may progress to sepsis or kidney damage if not properly treated.
7. HIV status: The patient's unknown HIV status poses a risk for HIV transmission and requires prompt evaluation and treatment.
8. Malaria relapse: The patient's history of falciparum malaria and current treatment with quinidine pose a risk for malaria relapse, which can be life-threatening.
9. Hypoglycemia: The patient's treatment with quinidine may cause hypoglycemia, which requires close monitoring and treatment.
10. Language barrier: The patient's language barrier may pose a challenge for communication and treatment, which requires accommodation and interpretation services.

Recommendations:

1. Continue quinidine drip for one more day and monitor for signs of seizure activity or hypoglycemia.
2. Evaluate the patient's language barrier and provide interpretation services as needed.
3. Monitor the patient's mental status and cognitive function closely.
4. Continue treatment for UTI and monitor for signs of sepsis or kidney damage.
5. Evaluate the patient's anemia and thrombocytopenia and consider further treatment or consultation.
6. Monitor the patient's liver function and consider further evaluation or treatment if necessary.
7. Evaluate the patient's HIV status and provide prompt treatment if necessary.
8. Consider further treatment or consultation for the patient's back pain and L-spine order.
9. Monitor the patient's seizure activity and consider further treatment or consultation if necessary.
10. Provide education and support to the patient and her family regarding her condition, treatment, and prognosis.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 24-year-old female from [**Country 1773**] with a history of recent falciparum malaria, presenting with altered mental status and seizures. The patient is currently in the ICU.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.2C, heart rate of 89 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 105/69 mmHg. She is oriented to person, place, and time, and follows simple commands.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 9.4 g/dL, and a platelet count of 346 K/uL. Her white blood cell count is 12.9 K/uL, and her creatinine level is 0.6 mg/dL. Her liver function tests are mildly elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 26 IU/L and an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 24 IU/L.

The patient's neurologic examination is significant for altered mental status, with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 12-22. She is hypoactive and apathetic, and may be experiencing depression or delirium. The patient's seizure activity is likely related to cerebral malaria, and she has been started on phosphenytoin and dilantin.

The patient's infection status is significant for falciparum malaria, and she is being treated with doxycycline. She has also had a urinary tract infection (UTI) in the past, and is being treated with antibiotics.

The patient's social situation is significant for a history of domestic violence and depression. She has been referred to social work and psychology for further evaluation and treatment.

Potential medical complications that can arise in this patient include:

1. Cerebral edema: The patient's altered mental status and seizures may be related to cerebral edema, which can be a complication of cerebral malaria.
2. Seizure activity: The patient's seizure activity may continue, and may be difficult to control with anticonvulsant medications.
3. Infection: The patient's falciparum malaria may progress, and may lead to serious complications such as respiratory failure or cardiac arrest.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen, and may lead to complications such as cardiac failure or respiratory failure.
5. Depression: The patient's depression may worsen, and may lead to suicidal ideation or attempts.
6. Delirium: The patient's delirium may worsen, and may lead to complications such as respiratory failure or cardiac arrest.

To mitigate these complications, the patient should be closely monitored for signs of cerebral edema, seizure activity, infection, anemia, depression, and delirium. She should also receive appropriate treatment for her falciparum malaria, and should be referred to social work and psychology for further evaluation and treatment.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-year-old female from [**Country 1773**] with a history of recent falciparum malaria, presenting with altered mental status and seizures, likely due to cerebral malaria. She has been treated with antimalarial medication and has shown some improvement in her mental status, but remains hypoactive and apathetic. She has also been experiencing seizures, which are likely related to the CSF infection and malaria. The patient has a history of depression and has made prior suicidal gestures, and a psych evaluation has been ordered.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cerebral malaria: The patient's altered mental status and seizures are likely due to cerebral malaria, which can lead to brain damage, coma, and even death if not treated promptly and effectively.
2. Seizure disorder: The patient's seizures may not be fully controlled, and there is a risk of further seizures, which can lead to injury or even death.
3. Depression: The patient's history of depression and suicidal gestures puts her at risk for further depression and suicidal behavior, which can be exacerbated by her current medical condition.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if not properly treated, leading to fatigue, weakness, and decreased immune function.
5. Malaria: The patient's falciparum malaria may not be fully treated, leading to relapse or complications such as organ failure or disseminated intravascular coagulation.
6. Delirium: The patient's hypoactive and apathetic state may be due to delirium, which can lead to further complications such as falls, pressure ulcers, and respiratory failure.
7. Fluid imbalance: The patient's fluid balance is critical, and there is a risk of dehydration or fluid overload, which can lead to organ failure or electrolyte imbalances.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antimalarial medication and monitor for signs of relapse or complications.
2. Adjust seizure medication as needed to control seizures.
3. Monitor the patient's mental status and cognitive function, and provide supportive care as needed.
4. Provide ongoing psychological support and evaluation to manage the patient's depression and suicidal risk.
5. Monitor the patient's anemia and provide transfusions as needed to maintain a stable hemoglobin level.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's fluid balance and adjust fluids as needed to prevent dehydration or fluid overload.
7. Consider consultation with a neurologist or psychiatrist to further evaluate and manage the patient's condition.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-year-old female with a history of falciparum malaria, presenting with altered mental status. She received plasma exchange transfusion on admission to decrease parasitemia. Her mental status has improved, and she is now following commands. The patient had a seizure on day 2, and EEG was performed, showing findings consistent with infection/inflammation. The patient is on quinidine drip, and ID and neuro recs will be followed. She is also on acyclovir, which was discontinued due to negative HSV PCR results.

The patient has a history of depression and suicide attempts and is a victim of domestic abuse. She is being followed by psych recs and social work.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.7C, heart rate of 72 bpm, and blood pressure of 99/56 mmHg. Her respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 98%.

The patient has anemia, which is being monitored. Her hemoglobin level is 8.9 g/dL, and her hematocrit is 25.9%. Her coagulation studies are normal, and DIC is less likely.

The patient is receiving IV quinidine, and ID recs will be followed regarding discontinuation. She is also receiving antimalarial treatment and will have further CSF studies, blood and urine cultures, and HIV testing once she is able to give consent.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Seizure recurrence: The patient had a seizure on day 2, and EEG showed findings consistent with infection/inflammation. Quinidine can cause QT prolongation, which may increase the risk of seizure recurrence.
2. Malaria relapse: Although the patient's parasitemia is negative, there is a risk of malaria relapse, especially if the patient does not receive adequate treatment.
3. Anemia worsening: The patient's anemia is being monitored, and further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of her anemia.
4. Infection: The patient is at risk of developing infections, especially given her compromised immune system due to malaria and potential co-infections.
5. Neurological sequelae: The patient's altered mental status and seizure may be indicative of neurological sequelae, which may require further evaluation and treatment.
6. Hypoglycemia: Quinidine can cause hypoglycemia, and the patient's blood glucose levels will need to be closely monitored.
7. QT prolongation: Quinidine can cause QT prolongation, which may increase the risk of arrhythmias and sudden cardiac death.
8. HIV infection: The patient's HIV status is unknown, and further testing is needed to determine her HIV status.

Recommendations:

1. Continue IV quinidine pending ID recs to stop.
2. Monitor the patient's mental status and seizure activity closely.
3. Perform further CSF studies, blood and urine cultures, and HIV testing once the patient is able to give consent.
4. Monitor the patient's anemia and coagulation studies closely.
5. Continue antimalarial treatment and monitor the patient's parasitemia.
6. Monitor the patient's blood glucose levels closely and treat hypoglycemia promptly.
7. Monitor the patient's QT interval and adjust quinidine dosing as needed.
8. Consider consulting a neurologist to further evaluate the patient's altered mental status and seizure activity.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 24-year-old female with a history of falciparum malaria, presenting with altered mental status. She received plasma exchange transfusion on the day of admission to decrease parasitemia, and her last smear was negative. The patient had a seizure on day 2, and an EEG was performed, which showed no acute danger. She is currently on quinidine drip and is expected to be weaned off it today.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.7C, heart rate of 72 bpm, and blood pressure of 99/56 mmHg. Her respiratory rate is 14 inspirations per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 98%. She is arousable to voice and follows commands, with sluggish movements.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 11.8 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 8.9 g/dL
* Platelet count: 299 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 0.6 mg/dL
* Glucose: 132 mg/dL
* Calcium: 8.5 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.0 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 4.1 mg/dL

The patient's medical history is significant for depression and suicide attempts, as well as being a victim of domestic abuse. She has a history of falciparum malaria and received plasma exchange transfusion on the day of admission.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Seizure recurrence due to quinidine toxicity or withdrawal
* Infection, such as bacterial or fungal meningitis, due to the patient's immunocompromised state
* Anemia or bleeding due to hemolysis or disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
* Hypoglycemia due to quinidine-induced hypoglycemia
* Malaria relapse or reinfection
* HIV infection, although the patient's HIV status is currently unknown
* Depression or suicidal ideation due to the patient's history of depression and domestic abuse

The patient's plan includes:

* Continued IV quinidine pending ID recs to stop
* Completion of 3 days of ceftriaxone for uncomplicated UTI
* Follow-up blood, urine, and CSF studies (sent for cultures, HSV PCR, Lyme, EEE, and West Nile virus)
* EKG to evaluate for QT prolongation on quinidine
* Follow-up parasite smears
* HIV status once the patient is able to give consent
* Seizure precautions
* Plan for 24-hour EEG soon per neuro
* Started Dilantin for seizures
* F/u psych recs
* Social work following
* Screen visitors

Overall, the patient's condition is stable, but she requires close monitoring for potential complications and continued treatment for her underlying infections.
